bioghist.p: Thomas Pym Cope was already an established Philadelphia merchant in 1821 when he began the first regular packet line between Philadelphia and Liverpool. The business continued throughout most of the nineteenth century, with the company name changing as successive generations assumed responsibility. The line also developed a sizable passenger business.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of the shipping firm Thomas P. Cope and Son. Materials include: bills of lading, manifests, and shipping articles for the ship Alexander, 1820s-1830s; bills of lading and letters addressed to Thomas P. Cope and Son related to the first voyage of the ship Tuscarora (1821-22). Many of the letters are sent from Liverpool and are signed Rathbone Hodgson (cotton merchants). Correspondence includes market reports. The collection also includes a photograph of Captain Julius and his family, 1889; business cards of Theodore Julius Jr., Commission Merchant; and an unsigned letter, presumably sent to Theodore Julius. [a rate card for Cope's Line of Philadelphia and Liverpool Packets -- not found in collection at time of survey, though there's a photograph of some of the collection materials that shows it, so it's been here in the recent past]
